maml:description.maml:para: Add a PI Trust

Identity name to use for this PI Trust.
Description of the PI trust
Network path to use for this PI Trust.

For PI API, this should match what the PI Data Archive thinks based on a reverse-name lookup using the interface's IP address. For PI SDK (1.3.6.x and later), this should match what the client thinks, based on the Windows configuration (you can use pidiag –host on the client to see this information). For example, my_laptop.my_company.com
IP address used for this trust. This is used in conjunction with NetMask.
NetMask used for this PI Trust. This is used in conjunction with the IP address.

If you require an exact match on an IP address, specify the NetMask as 255.255.255.255. If you specify a class C subnet, specify the NetMask as 255.255.255.0 and the fourth field of the IP address as 0.
The Windows domain of the user who runs the application.
The Windows user name of the user who runs the application.
For applications that connect through the SDK, use the full name of the connecting application, including the extension, but not the path. For example, the application name for PI ICU is: PI-ICU.exe

Applications that connect through the API send an identifier called an application process name, or procname. This is a four-character string with an E appended. For example, the procname for the Perfmon interface is: PIPeE

Note: PI API versions before 1.6.0 always send a five-character string: 4 characters plus a capital E. For PI API versions 1.6.0 and later, up to 8 characters may be specified as the procname, if configured to do so (in this case, there is no longer an E appended to the procname).

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command connects to the specified PI Data Archive and returns a PI Data Archive connection object. PISRV1 is the name of either a standalone PI Data Archive or a specific PI collective member. For connecting to a PI Collective, see example: Connect using Connection Configuration.

Credential : SecurityModes: Windows|Trust Identity : PIAdministrators | PIEngineers Principal : TestDomain\TestUser OperationTimeout : 00:01:00 OpenTimeout : 00:00:10 Behavior : Type: Reconnect ServerVersion : 3.4.390.18 CurrentRole : Name: PISRV1; Type: UnSpecified Address : pi://PISRV1/ Directory : OSIsoft.PI.Configuration.PISDKRegistryDirectoryProvider Service : Service: Name = PISRV1; Service Id = 14e1bf4d-df7e-464a-a617-78edf6bd11f0; type = Standalone Configuration : Name PISRV1 LoginMode : SSPI_Implicit OperatingSystemUserName : TestDomain\TestUser SessionID : 0 Name : Connected : True Uid : c4e8a3cc-6d88-4fbb-b556-7c415dfcbfeb DisconnectedByUser : False

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Connect using Connection Configuration --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Connect-PIDataArchive -PIDataArchiveConnectionConfiguration (Get-PIDataArchiveConnectionConfiguration -name PIDA1)
or
Get-PIDataArchiveConnectionConfiguration -name PIDA1 | Connect-PIDataArchive

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command connects to a PI Data Archive or PI Collective using a PIDataArchiveConnectionConfiguration object, which is returned by the command Get-PIDataArchiveConnectionConfiguration. Note PIDA1 can be the name of a PI collective, a PI collective member, or a standalone PI Data Archive. This returns a PI Data Archive connection object.

This command will connect to the specified PI Data Archive using Windows Integrated Security and the user TestDomain\TestUser. If -WindowsCredential is not specified, it will use the user that launched Powershell. OpenTimeout sets the connection timeout (amount of time allowed to connect to the PI Data Archive) to 30 seconds. OperationTimeout sets the data access timeout (amount of time allowed to complete an operation, such as a data query) to 10 minutes. If these timeouts are not specified, they will default to the values set in the PI SDK Utility Connections Manager. These parameter overrides (timeouts and AuthenticationMethod) only work when using PIDataArchiveMachineName, not with PIDataArchiveConnectionConfiguration.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will return the daily time-weighted average of the default sinusoid tag for each day in the month of February. The start time of the query is the first entry in the $times array (1-Feb-2015 00:00:00) and the end time is the second array value, 1-Mar-2015 00:00:00. The -Intervals parameters is the number of equal segments you want to split the time range into, in this case 28. Since there are 28 days from 1-Feb to 1-Mar, this becomes a daily average.

The result of this cmdlet ($results) is a hash table (a key-value pair object). Data can be extracted from the table in a variety of ways. One way would be to do: $results.Value.Values[0] to return the summary start times. $results.Value.Values[1] to return the summary end times. $results.Value.Values[2] to return the summary values. $results.Value.Values[3] to return the percent good of the summary queries.
This example will return the daily time-weighted average of the sum of two tags, sinusoid and cdt158, for each day in January and February of 2015.

In this case we are querying over two separate intervals, the first from 1-Jan-2015 to 1-Feb-2015 with 31 intervals (for 31 days in January), and the second from 1-Feb-2015 to 1-Mar-2015 with 28 intervals (for 28 days in February). Note the way this works: our first time range is going to use: Starttime = $times[0] = "1-Jan-2015 00:00:00" Endtime = $times[1] = "1-Feb-2015 00:00:00" Interval = $int[0] = 31
The second time range is going to use Starttime = $times[1] = "1-Feb-2015 00:00:00" EndTime = $times[2] = "1-Mar-2015 00:00:00" Interval = $int[1] = 28

Note that -Times takes an array of timestamps, -Intervals takes either a single integer value or an array of integer values, and -Expression takes a valid PI Expression, which uses the same syntax as PI Performance Equations. The result of this cmdlet ($results) is a hash table (a key-value pair object). See the previous example (Uniform Time Interval) for an example of how to extract data from the hash table.

The Set-PIDigitalStateSet sets all PI Digital States in a single PI Digital State Set.
The Connection parameter specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.

All PI Digital States to include in the PI Digital State Set being edited.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Name of PI Digital State Set to edit.
All PI Digital States to include in the PI Digital State Set being edited.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
This cmdlet accepts a ClientChannel as the connection to operate against.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the digital state set Cycle to have 4 states:
0 - Preparing 1 - Washing 2 - Spinning 3 - Drying
This will overwrite any pre-existing digital states in the digital state set.

command:example.dev:code: Set-PIIdentity -Name PIEngineers -Description "Generic PI Identity for engineers" -CanDelete 0 -Enabled 1 -AllowUseInMappings 1 -AllowUseInTrusts 0 -AllowExplicitLogin 0 -Connection $con

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command edits the PI Identity named PIEngineers to have a description of "Generic PI Identity for engineers", disallows deletion of the identity, enables the identity, allows the identity to be used in mappings, and disallows the identity to be used in trusts and explicit logins.

maml:description.maml:para: Set PI Trust information
The Set-PITrust cmdlet edits information about an existing PI Trust.
The Connection parameter specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Name of the PI Trust to edit.
Identity for PI Trust to use
Description of PI Trust
Network path to use for this PI Trust.

For PI API, this should match what the PI Data Archive thinks based on a reverse-name lookup using the interface's IP address. For PI SDK (1.3.6.x and later), this should match what the client thinks, based on the Windows configuration (you can use pidiag –host on the client to see this information). For example, my_laptop.my_company.com
IP address used for this trust. This is used in conjunction with NetMask.
NetMask used for this PI Trust. This is used in conjunction with the IP address.

If you require an exact match on an IP address, specify the NetMask as 255.255.255.255. If you specify a class C subnet, specify the NetMask as 255.255.255.0 and the fourth field of the IP address as 0.
The Windows domain of the user who runs the application.
The Windows user name of the user who runs the application.
For applications that connect through the SDK, use the full name of the connecting application, including the extension, but not the path. For example, the application name for PI ICU is: PI-ICU.exe

Applications that connect through the API send an identifier called an application process name, or procname. This is a four-character string with an E appended. For example, the procname for the Perfmon interface is: PIPeE

Note: PI API versions before 1.6.0 always send a five-character string: 4 characters plus a capital E. For PI API versions 1.6.0 and later, up to 8 characters may be specified as the procname, if configured to do so (in this case, there is no longer an E appended to the procname).
Disable this PI Trust.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Name of the PI Trust to edit.
Identity for PI Trust to use
Description of PI Trust
Network path to use for this PI Trust.

For PI API, this should match what the PI Data Archive thinks based on a reverse-name lookup using the interface's IP address. For PI SDK (1.3.6.x and later), this should match what the client thinks, based on the Windows configuration (you can use pidiag –host on the client to see this information). For example, my_laptop.my_company.com
IP address used for this trust. This is used in conjunction with NetMask.
NetMask used for this PI Trust. This is used in conjunction with the IP address.

If you require an exact match on an IP address, specify the NetMask as 255.255.255.255. If you specify a class C subnet, specify the NetMask as 255.255.255.0 and the fourth field of the IP address as 0.
The Windows domain of the user who runs the application.
The Windows user name of the user who runs the application.
For applications that connect through the SDK, use the full name of the connecting application, including the extension, but not the path. For example, the application name for PI ICU is: PI-ICU.exe

Applications that connect through the API send an identifier called an application process name, or procname. This is a four-character string with an E appended. For example, the procname for the Perfmon interface is: PIPeE

Note: PI API versions before 1.6.0 always send a five-character string: 4 characters plus a capital E. For PI API versions 1.6.0 and later, up to 8 characters may be specified as the procname, if configured to do so (in this case, there is no longer an E appended to the procname).
Disable this PI Trust.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
This cmdlet accepts a ClientChannel as the connection to operate against.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Set-PITrust -Name OPCInterface1 -Identity PIInterfaces -Description "Trust for the OPC interfaces on the OPC PINS node" -NetworkPath OPC_PINS -ApplicationName OPCiE -Disabled 0 -Connection $con

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command edits the pre-existing PI Trust named OPCInterface1 to use the PI Identity PIInterfaces, and to have a description of "Trust for the OPC interfaces on the OPC PINS node", a network path of OPC_PINS, an application name of OPCiE, and the trust is enabled.

maml:description.maml:para: Set the password for an existing PI User

The Set-PIUserPassword cmdlet sets the password for an existing PI User. The existing password must be known to be able to reset. If the existing password is not known, login as "piadmin" and use "!" as the old password.
The password must be passed in as a secure string. The ConvertTo-SecureString cmdlet can be used to generate the secure string.
The Connection parameter specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Name of PI User to change password for.
Existing password
New password
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Name of PI User to change password for.
Existing password
New password
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
This cmdlet accepts a ClientChannel as the connection to operate against.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the password of PIUser12 from piuser to newP@ssw0rd.

maml:description.maml:para: Start a Batch Database analysis

The Start-PIAFLinkBatchDatabaseAnalysis cmdlet will start an analysis of the Batch Database and generate an XML report for review. This report is useful for finding and solving any issues before migrating the Batch Database to Event Frames in AF.
The Connection parameter specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
This cmdlet accepts a ClientChannel as the connection to operate against.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command start an analysis of the Batch Database for the specified PI Data Archive.

maml:description.maml:para: Start a Batch Database migration

The Start-PIAFLinkBatchDatabaseMigration cmdlet will start the migration process for copying all Batch Database information to Event Frames in AF. The AF Server, Database, and Element that this information is put in is determined by the settings that were used in the Module Database to AF synchronization settings.
Once a Batch Database to Event Frames migration has taken place, the Batch Database is read only.
The Connection parameter specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
This cmdlet accepts a ClientChannel as the connection to operate against.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command begins the Batch Database to Event Frames migration process for the specified PI Data Archive.

maml:description.maml:para: Start a PI Backup
The Start-PIBackup cmdlet will start a PI Backup. The status of the PI Backup can be monitored with the Get-PIBackupState cmdlet.
The Connection parameter specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Location to backup files to.
Number of archives to include in the backup.
Do not include archives that are older than this date.
Archive index list of archives to include in the PI Backup.
Type of backup to perform. The valid options are:
Copy Incremental Differential Full
List of components to include in the PI Backup. A component list can be found with Get-PIBackupIdentifyReport
List of components to exclude from this PI Backup. A component list can be found with Get-PIBackupIdentifyReport
Do not include future archives on servers that support htem.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.

Copy Incremental Differential Full

Do not include future archives on servers that support htem.
Archive index list of archives to include in the PI Backup.
List of components to include in the PI Backup. A component list can be found with Get-PIBackupIdentifyReport
This cmdlet accepts a ClientChannel as the connection to operate against.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command starts a backup on the specified PI Data Archive. The backup location is E:\PI\Backups, and it will backup at least the 3 most recent archive (-NumberOfArchives 3), plus any files that have changed since the previous backup (-Type Incremental).
If NumberOfArchives is not specified, a normal incremental backup will be performed (only files that have changed since the previous backup would be backed up).

This command will start a Copy type backup on the specified PI Data Archive. The backup will be saved to E:\PI\Backups, and will include archive files with indexes 0 (the current primary archive), 3, and 4 from the historical archive set.
If -ArchiveIndex is not specified, all archives in both the historical and future archive sets will be back up. To only backup historical archives, use the -ExcludeFuture switch.

maml:description.maml:para: Stop a running PI Backup
The Stop-PIBackup cmdlet stops a currently running PI Backup.
The Connection parameter specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
This cmdlet accepts a ClientChannel as the connection to operate against.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command aborts any backup that is in progress on the specified PI Data Archive.

maml:description.maml:para: Unregister a PI Archive
The Unregister-PIArchive cmdlet unregisters a registered PI Archive. An unregistered PI Archive is not deleted, but the PI Data Archive will no longer see the data in it until it is re-registered.
The Connection parameter specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Full path and file name to PI Archive to be unregistered.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
Full path and file name to PI Archive to be unregistered.
Specifies which connection to a PI Data Archive to use.
This cmdlet accepts a ClientChannel as the connection to operate against.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command unregisters the archive file with the name E:\Program Files\PI\arc\piarch.238.

Add one or more PI Values to a PI Data Archive

The Add-PIValue cmdlet will add one or more PI Values to the specified PI Data Archive. If multiple values are being written, the number of values in the array's that are passed in must either be 1 or the same number as each other.
Example #1: Time: 1/1/2000 Value: 50 PointName: Sinusoid, Sinusoidu, CDT158
Valid. This would write the value of 50 at 1/1/2000 for all three points.
Example #2: Time: 1/1/2000 Value: 50, 51, 52 PointName: Sinusoid, Sinusoidu, CDT158
Valid. This would write 50 to Sinusoid, 51 to Sinusoidu, and 52 to CDT158, all at 1/1/2000.
Example #3 Time: 1/1/2000 Value: 50, 51 PointName: Sinusoid, Sinusoidu, CDT158
Invalid. The array size of Value and PointName are greater than one, so they must be the same.

Specify if value or values should have the Questionable bit set
